is document is prepared by the Azure

Microsoft Azure is a cloud computing platform and infrastructure created by Microsoft for building, deploying, and managing applications and services through a global network of Microsoft-managed datacenters. It provides SaaS, PaaS and IaaS services and supports many different programming languages, tools and frameworks, including both Microsoft-specific and third-party software and systems. Microsoft Azure allows you to quickly deploy infrastructures and services to meet all your business needs. You can run Windows and Linux applications in 30 Azure Datacenter regions, delivered with enterprise SLA.
By moving to Microsoft Azure cloud, you can:
Instantly scale up and down, depending on your business needs
Run your operations more cost effectively, by paying only for what you use
Free up budget from hefty capital expenses on on-premise hardware
Gain enterprise-level security and automated data backup

can use License Mobility to bring licenses on premise.

This section details out how customers can benefit most out of their own software licenses in cloud. License Mobility through Software Assurance gives you the flexibility to adopt cloud on your own terms while preserving the licensing investments.

This section recommends which of the licenses in the current discovered environment can be considered for License Mobility to cloud. However license verification for actual License mobility through Software Assurance will happen during the migration phase.
Following table depicts the total monthly azure spend for compute, storage and network considering the Licensing Mobility recommended above
Decision making around use of cloud services can be complex and estimating the ROI is a critical part of ensuring that the path taken is the right one.

ROI Analysis is the key component to help the customer understand and evaluate the financial benefits of Azure cloud adoption. Analysis of cloud ROI takes into consideration several traditional factors such as hardware, software, network, product costs and other overheads that would be applicable for on-premise environment. Moving to cloud brings in new factors such as reduced need for data center space, reduced operational expenses and a
void building for maximum loads. Moving from Capex to Opex allows
customer to benefit from Pay-as-you-go pricing plans of Azure with no up-front costs and no minimal requirement.

On-premise costs are based on hardware configurations provisioned along with software/OS licensing costs. In some cases, customers’ legacy hardware configurations would not map 1:1 to available options in ROI calculator. Hence there would be minimal deviation of on-premise costing. **

the actual workload and usage characteristics. Some of the parameters considered during the workload mapping to azure are CPU usage, peak memory usage, peak network usage, unused storage capacity, disk IOPS etc. This provides
